content.description: Sit start low, solid right foot and a decent left foot stem. Work up the finger crack and try to find a bomber hand jam.
content.location: First corner of the downhill side on the second outcropping. Left of the Once and Future Flake.

content.description: Sit start low with a side pull undercling combo. Reach up high and get your foot up on the first slab. From here pull the next two "roofs" to the top. Fun slabby climb with a semi burly sit start.
content.location: On a corner of the second boulder outcrop. Downhill side.

content.description: Start on a juggy rail and cross under the boulder. Look for the block that looks like it'll pop on the other side. Reach for the top.
content.location: Jut of rock that is across from the main overlook. Climb left to right, staying in the chasm.

content.description: Sit start on the arete left of Pops. Do not pull onto the face, rather dangle and move upwards. Topping out on the arete and left of the corner.
content.location: Left of Pops in the Corner

content.description: Start out with a combination of hand and foot jams. Donut, hand, and fist jams can all be utilized on this short route. Top out is easy.
content.location: On the corner of the overhanging side and foot jam side

content.description: Start on a muggy rail and work your way to a flat top out. Either dyno or utilize decent edges on this slightly overhung corner.
content.location: Right of Eaves Travers, pass under the main ledge and into a walled path area.

content.description: Utilize a side pull and the arete to pull out of a sit start. Watch for the dab. Move up and right along the arete.
content.protection: Pad and a spotter to move it.
content.location: On the corner of the overhang section and the vertical layered section.

content.description: Stand start on the lowest horizontal ledge. Pop up to each level and work left to the arete between two trees. The crux is not dabbing on the trees. A pad can be slotted between the trees in a v shape. Works well for falls going for the top holds.
content.location: Left side of the eave traverse, look for the tree trunks and the arete.

content.description:
For shorter people, the crux is reaching for the top hold. Tricky balance moves. 

 Otherwise the crux is the traverse right from the starting holds.
content.protection: Crash pad at the start and a spotter in case you roll down the back boulder.
content.location:
From the lookout boulder move downhill into the woods to the other nearby boulder.

 Start on the uncut flakr that will one day break. Left foot on a numbing and right foot wherever.

content.description: Start on the Aleutian and traverse start. Work your way straight up. Avoiding dabbing the tree. Relatively tough topout for the grade and rocky ridge.One can also start on the right side of the traverse, move left under the eave, and up for fun link up.
Start out with some foot jams and a hand jam. Short crack but good for practicing foot jams. Top out is a little sketchy for the grade.
content.location: On the furthest side of the boulder from the lookout view.

content.description: Sit start on crimps and a bomber foot. Work up and top out on the large thin boulder that rests atop of the block. Crux is keeping your balance. Be careful not to dab or chimney your way out.
content.location: In the channel between the main blocks. Opposite the slinking arete.

content.description: Start under the lookout view ledg on the left side. Traverse along the horizontal crack with bomber handholds but iffy feet. Crux is near the end at the finishing hold. Be wary of the rock in the middle and towards the end.Alternatively, you can start on the right side and traverse left. Linking in a climb for the top out.
content.protection: Multiple pads or one and a spotter
content.location: When stop the lookout boulder, descend the right side and face the lookout boulder. Traverse starts on the left side typically but either work.

content.description: Start on a jug and work the lip up and to the rock's point. Pull up on an easy topout. Watch dabbing on the rock below.
content.location: From the main overlook, look across the small span to a toothlike rock. Drop down and work into a small gully with the tooth as a roof.

content.description: Conglomerate Rock, popular with hikers to walk out to. Some roof problems, traverses, and short crack problems. There are two main outcroppings. One with an obvious ledge/roof and the other with slightly overhanging sides and a few short crack problems.
